Sorted Collections Interview Notes

Rapid overview
  • Sorted Collections & Interview Talking Points

Sorted Collections & Interview Talking Points

| Collection | Ordering | Duplicates | Big-O (lookup/insert) | Interview Highlights | | ---------- | -------- | ---------- | ---------------------- | -------------------- | | List<T> + List<T>.Sort() | Custom comparer | Allows duplicates | Lookup: O(n), Insert (sorted): O(n) | Use when you can sort once and traverse. Mention Array.Sort vs List<T>.Sort and Span<T> overloads. | | SortedList<TKey,TValue> | Sorted by key (array-backed) | Keys must be unique | Lookup: O(log n), Insert: O(n) | Compact memory footprint, but expensive inserts due to array shifts. Great for mostly-read scenarios. | | SortedDictionary<TKey,TValue> | Sorted by key (red-black tree) | Keys must be unique | Lookup/Insert: O(log n) | Balanced tree handles frequent inserts/removals better than SortedList. | | SortedSet<T> | Sorted by value (tree) | No duplicates | Lookup/Insert: O(log n) | Ideal for maintaining a sorted unique setâ€”mention GetViewBetween. | | PriorityQueue<TElement,TPriority> | Min-heap by priority | Allows duplicates | Enqueue: O(log n), Peek: O(1) | Perfect for Dijkstra/A* discussions. Talk about customizing priority comparer. |

ðŸ§  Practice Prompt: Explain how youâ€™d pick between SortedList and SortedDictionary for a price ladder updated multiple times per second.
